description:
Provides insights about processes running on Linux host, such as Per Process CPU and  Memory Usage, Disk IO, Process status etc 

To be used with Percona Monitoring and Management v2 (PMM2)

panels.description: The parameter shows how long a system has been “up” and running without a shut down or restart.
panels.title: System Uptime

panels.description: The system load is a measurement of the computational work the system is performing. Each running process either using or waiting for CPU resources adds 1 to the load.
panels.title: Load Average

panels.description: RAM (Random Access Memory) is the hardware in a computing device where the operating system, application programs and data in current use are kept so they can be quickly reached by the device's processor.
panels.title: RAM

panels.description:
Percent of Memory Available
Note: on Modern Linux Kernels amount of Memory Available for application is not the same as Free+Cached+Buffers
panels.title: Memory Available

panels.description: The CPU time is measured in clock ticks or seconds. It is useful to measure CPU time as a percentage of the CPU's capacity, which is called the CPU usage.

targets.expr: avg by (node_name,mode) (clamp_max(((avg by (mode,node_name) ( (clamp_max(rate(node_cpu_seconds_total{node_name=~"$node_name",mode!="idle"}[$interval]),1)) or (clamp_max(irate(node_cpu_seconds_total{node_name=~"$node_name",mode!="idle"}[5m]),1)) ))*100 or (avg_over_time(node_cpu_average{node_name=~"$node_name", mode!="total", mode!="idle"}[$interval]) or avg_over_time(node_cpu_average{node_name=~"$node_name", mode!="total", mode!="idle"}[5m]))),100))

panels.title: CPU Usage

panels.description: When a system is running with maximum CPU utilization, the transmitting and receiving threads must all share the available CPU. This will cause data to be queued more frequently to cope with the lack of CPU. CPU Saturation may be measured as the length of a wait queue, or the time spent waiting on the queue.
panels.title: CPU Saturation and Max Core Usage
Top processes by Total CPU cores used
Top processes by System CPU cores used

targets.expr:
clamp_min(avg by (node_name) (((avg_over_time(node_memory_MemTotal_bytes{node_name=~"$node_name"}[$interval]) or avg_over_time(node_memory_MemTotal_bytes{node_name=~"$node_name"}[5m])) - ((avg_over_time(node_memory_MemFree_bytes{node_name=~"$node_name"}[$interval]) or avg_over_time(node_memory_MemFree_bytes{node_name=~"$node_name"}[5m]))+ 
(avg_over_time(node_memory_Buffers_bytes{node_name=~"$node_name"}[$interval]) or avg_over_time(node_memory_Buffers_bytes{node_name=~"$node_name"}[5m])) + 
(avg_over_time(node_memory_Cached_bytes{node_name=~"$node_name"}[$interval]) or avg_over_time(node_memory_Cached_bytes{node_name=~"$node_name"}[5m]))))),0)

avg by (node_name) (
(avg_over_time(node_memory_SwapFree_bytes{node_name="$node_name"}[$interval]) or avg_over_time(node_memory_SwapFree_bytes{node_name="$node_name"}[5m])) + ((avg_over_time(node_memory_MemAvailable_bytes{node_name="$node_name"}[$interval]) or avg_over_time(node_memory_MemAvailable_bytes{node_name="$node_name"}[5m])) or
((avg_over_time(node_memory_MemFree_bytes{node_name="$node_name"}[$interval]) or avg_over_time(node_memory_MemFree_bytes{node_name="$node_name"}[5m]))+
(avg_over_time(node_memory_Buffers_bytes{node_name="$node_name"}[$interval]) or avg_over_time(node_memory_Buffers_bytes{node_name="$node_name"}[5m]))+
(avg_over_time(node_memory_Cached_bytes{node_name="$node_name"}[$interval]) or avg_over_time(node_memory_Cached_bytes{node_name="$node_name"}[5m]))))
)

avg by (node_name) (
((avg_over_time(node_memory_MemTotal_bytes{node_name="$node_name"}[$interval]) or avg_over_time(node_memory_MemTotal_bytes{node_name="$node_name"}[5m])) +
(avg_over_time(node_memory_SwapTotal_bytes{node_name="$node_name"}[$interval]) or avg_over_time(node_memory_SwapTotal_bytes{node_name="$node_name"}[5m]))) -
((avg_over_time(node_memory_SwapFree_bytes{node_name="$node_name"}[$interval]) or avg_over_time(node_memory_SwapFree_bytes{node_name="$node_name"}[5m])) + ((avg_over_time(node_memory_MemAvailable_bytes{node_name="$node_name"}[$interval]) or avg_over_time(node_memory_MemAvailable_bytes{node_name="$node_name"}[5m])) or
((avg_over_time(node_memory_MemFree_bytes{node_name="$node_name"}[$interval]) or avg_over_time(node_memory_MemFree_bytes{node_name="$node_name"}[5m]))+
(avg_over_time(node_memory_Buffers_bytes{node_name="$node_name"}[$interval]) or avg_over_time(node_memory_Buffers_bytes{node_name="$node_name"}[5m]))+
(avg_over_time(node_memory_Cached_bytes{node_name="$node_name"}[$interval]) or avg_over_time(node_memory_Cached_bytes{node_name="$node_name"}[5m])))))
)

panels.description: Swap Activity is memory management that involves swapping sections of memory to and from physical storage.
panels.title: Swap Activity

panels.description: Amount of Memory Process has in RAM. For Memory  shared by multiple process,  space is divided among them for purpose of computation

targets.formattedQuery: SELECT $timeSeries as t, count() FROM $table WHERE $timeFilter GROUP BY t ORDER BY t
targets.query:
SELECT
    $timeSeries as t,
    count()
FROM $table

WHERE $timeFilter

GROUP BY t

ORDER BY t

panels.title: Top processes by Resident Memory (Proportional)

panels.description: Memory Used by Processes, counted as Resident Memory + Space used in Swap Space
panels.title: Top processes by Used  memory (Proportional)

panels.description: Disk I/O includes read or write or input/output operations involving a physical disk. It is the speed with which the data transfer takes place between the hard disk drive and RAM.

targets.expr:
avg by (node_name) ((rate(node_vmstat_pgpgin{node_name=~"$node_name"}[$interval]) * 1024 or irate(node_vmstat_pgpgin{node_name=~"$node_name"}[5m]) * 1024 ) + (rate(node_vmstat_pgpgout{node_name=~"$node_name"}[$interval]) * 1024 or irate(node_vmstat_pgpgout{node_name=~"$node_name"}[5m]) * 1024) or
((max_over_time(rdsosmetrics_diskIO_writeKbPS{node_name=~"$node_name"}[$interval]) or max_over_time(rdsosmetrics_diskIO_writeKbPS{node_name=~"$node_name"}[5m])) +
(max_over_time(rdsosmetrics_diskIO_readKbPS{node_name=~"$node_name"}[$interval]) or max_over_time(rdsosmetrics_diskIO_readKbPS{node_name=~"$node_name"}[5m])))* 1024)

panels.title: I/O Activity

panels.description: Shows average latency for Reads and Writes IO Devices.  Higher than typical latency for highly loaded storage indicates saturation (overload) and is frequent cause of performance problems.  Higher than normal latency also can indicate internal storage problems.

targets.expr:
avg by (node_name) ((sum by (node_name) (rate(node_disk_read_time_seconds_total{node_name=~"$node_name"}[$interval])) / sum by (node_name) (rate(node_disk_reads_completed_total{node_name=~"$node_name"}[$interval]) > 0 )) or (sum by (node_name) (irate(node_disk_read_time_seconds_total{node_name=~"$node_name"}[5m])) / 
sum by (node_name) (irate(node_disk_reads_completed_total{node_name=~"$node_name"}[5m]) > 0 ))
or avg_over_time(aws_rds_read_latency_average{node_name=~"$node_name"}[$interval])/1000 or avg_over_time(aws_rds_read_latency_average{node_name=~"$node_name"}[5m])/1000 or
avg_over_time(rdsosmetrics_diskIO_readLatency{node_name=~"$node_name"}[$interval])/1000 or avg_over_time(rdsosmetrics_diskIO_readLatency{node_name=~"$node_name"}[5m])/1000)

avg by (node_name) ((sum by (node_name) (rate(node_disk_write_time_seconds_total{node_name=~"$node_name"}[$interval])) / sum by (node_name) (rate(node_disk_writes_completed_total{node_name=~"$node_name"}[$interval]) > 0 )) or (sum by (node_name) (irate(node_disk_write_time_seconds_total{node_name=~"$node_name"}[5m])) / 
sum by (node_name) (irate(node_disk_writes_completed_total{node_name=~"$node_name"}[5m]) > 0 ))
or (avg_over_time(aws_rds_write_latency_average{node_name=~"$node_name"}[$interval])/1000 or avg_over_time(aws_rds_write_latency_average{node_name=~"$node_name"}[5m])/1000) or
(avg_over_time(rdsosmetrics_diskIO_writeLatency{node_name=~"$node_name"}[$interval]) or avg_over_time(rdsosmetrics_diskIO_writeLatency{node_name=~"$node_name"}[5m]))/1000)

avg by (node_name) ((sum by (node_name) (rate(node_disk_read_time_seconds_total{node_name=~"$node_name"}[1h])) / sum by (node_name) (rate(node_disk_reads_completed_total{node_name=~"$node_name"}[1h]) > 0 ))
or avg_over_time(aws_rds_read_latency_average{node_name=~"$node_name"}[1h])/1000 or avg_over_time(aws_rds_read_latency_average{node_name=~"$node_name"}[1h])/1000 or
avg_over_time(rdsosmetrics_diskIO_readLatency{node_name=~"$node_name"}[1h])/1000 or avg_over_time(rdsosmetrics_diskIO_readLatency{node_name=~"$node_name"}[1h])/1000)

avg by (node_name) ((sum by (node_name) (rate(node_disk_write_time_seconds_total{node_name=~"$node_name"}[1h])) / sum by (node_name) (rate(node_disk_writes_completed_total{node_name=~"$node_name"}[1h]) > 0 )) 
or (avg_over_time(aws_rds_write_latency_average{node_name=~"$node_name"}[$interval])/1000 or avg_over_time(aws_rds_write_latency_average{node_name=~"$node_name"}[1h])/1000) or
(avg_over_time(rdsosmetrics_diskIO_writeLatency{node_name=~"$node_name"}[$interval])/1000 or avg_over_time(rdsosmetrics_diskIO_writeLatency{node_name=~"$node_name"}[1h])/1000))

panels.title: Disk IO Latency
Top processes by number of  processes instances
Top processes by number of threads

panels.description:
Interrupt is an input signal to the processor indicating an event that needs immediate attention. An interrupt signal alerts the processor and serves as a request for the processor to interrupt the currently executing code, so that the event can be processed in a timely manner.

Context switch is the process of storing the state of a process or thread, so that it can be restored and resume execution at a later point. This allows multiple processes to share a single CPU, and is an essential feature of a multitasking operating system.
panels.title: Interrupts and Context Switches

panels.description: Voluntary Context switches happen when process leaves CPU because it has nothing else to do - it need to wait for IO completion, lock event etc.  Very high number of context switches tend to indicate inefficient operation
panels.title: Top Processes by Voluntary Context Switches

panels.description: Non-Voluntary Context Switches happen when scheduler forcibly suspends active thread, even if it could continue running. This typically happens when thread needs to be preempted by a different thread such as having higher priority or when thread exhausted its CPU clice
panels.title: Top Processes by  Non-Voluntary Context Switches
Top processes by Open File Descriptors
Top processes by File Descriptor Usage Percent

panels.description: Major page fault occurs when process accesses page which is not in memory and typically needs to be brought up to memory through disk io.
panels.title: Top processes by Major Page Faults

panels.description: Minor page faults happen when page is not mapped to the address space of the given process but otherwise is in memory. As such Minor page faults are less expensive than Major page faults and typically do not require disk IO.  The do require switch to kernel space and for kernel to do some housekeeping
panels.title: Top processes by Minor Page Faults
Top of processes waiting on IO

title: Linux Processes
